statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: George Mason 79, Cleveland State 74
article.story: CLEVELAND (AP) -- There were no new T-shirts or baseball caps being handed out. After the final horn, none of the winning players celebrated with a dance, and Cinderella's name didn't get mentioned once. That's all in the past for George Mason. On Saturday, this group of Patriots set off to make their own history. Will Thomas scored a career-high 25 points and George Mason, last season's surprise Final Four squad, finally woke up after halftime for a 79-74 win in its opener against Cleveland State. Thomas, one of two starters back from the Patriots' team that shocked some of college basketball's big boys during a magical NCAA tournament run in March, added 10 rebounds and helped George Mason overcome a 16-point, first-half deficit. "This is a new season and a new team," said Patriots coach Jim Larranaga. "This is a team that has to develop an identity." Until it does, George Mason will be best remembered for its unexpected romp as lovable underdogs in last season's NCAA tourney. After barely squeaking in, the Colonial Athletic Association's Patriots beat Michigan State, North Carolina, Wichita State and top-seeded Connecticut to make the Final Four. Asked for his most vivid memory, Thomas recalled the Patriots' stunning upset of the Huskies. "Probably getting the hats and T-shirts after we beat UConn," he said. Thomas then looked at Larranaga, and the two shared a laugh reliving a moment that shocked the basketball world. For a while Saturday, George Mason nearly got a surprise from Cleveland State. The Vikings had a 9-point halftime lead and still led by eight with 8:49 remaining. But the Patriots, who shot 73 percent (19-of-26) from the floor after halftime, made four consecutive 3-pointers -- the last by Jordan Carter -- to take a 68-67 lead with 4:40 left. George Mason then employed a 2-3 zone defense that Larranaga rarely has his team practice to take away Cleveland State's outside game in the final minutes. John Vaughn added 18 points, Folarin Campbell 14 and Darryl Monroe, a 6-foot-7, 260-pound junior college transfer, had 14 points -- all in the second half -- for George Mason, which had six turnovers in the second half after getting 11 in the first 20 minutes. J'Nathan Bullock scored 22 points and freshman Joe Davis 19 to lead Cleveland State, playing its first game under coach Gary Waters. He left Rutgers after four seasons and is trying to turn around a program that hasn't been to the NCAA tourney in 20 years. "We gave this game away," Waters said. "I thought we played well enough to win. I've got to teach these guys how to do the right things at the end." Playing on a much smaller stage than they enjoyed in March, the Patriots played sloppily for 30 minutes before using some of the tournament experience they gained last season to put away the Vikings. Taking advantage of its size, George Mason pounded the ball inside to Thomas and Monroe in the second half. Still, Cleveland State was within three at 74-71 with 35.6 seconds to go when Victor Morris made two free throws. Campbell then missed a free throw with 20.1 seconds left, and Cleveland State's Bullock grabbed the rebound underneath before it was poked away by Patriots guard Gabe Norwood. Vaughn made two free throws and after a Cleveland State miss, Carter made one to put George Mason ahead 77-71. Davis' fifth 3-pointer got the Vikings within three, but Campbell made two free throws to ice it for George Mason. "There's no satisfaction," Cleveland State guard Victor Morris said. "We came into this game wanting to win." Just 3 minutes in, George Mason had five turnovers and the Patriots fell trailed 23-18 before reeling off six straight points. However, Davis drained consecutive 3s and the Vikings went on a 14-2 run, building a 39-23 lead on Bullock's layup. But the Patriots, finally playing with some care and confidence, broke off a 9-2 spurt to pull to 41-32 at halftime. "You have to give a lot of credit to Gary Waters and Cleveland State for the way they came out," Larranaga said. "They really controlled the tempo early."
